metadata.sermon_start_end: Eternal God, who alone dost rule the ragings of the sea and whose name is high above every name. We bow in awe and reverence before thee. [...] He prepareth a table before me in the presence of mine enemies. He anointeth my head with oil. He maketh my cup to run over. He hath, and he will.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails significantly to focus on a specific Bible passage. While Isaiah 2:3 is cited at the beginning, it is immediately abandoned for Matthew 25:34, which then serves as a springboard for general thematic reflections on God's kindness. There is no attempt to find what is unique to Isaiah 2:3 or even the Matthew text; instead, the preacher uses the texts as 'biblical keywords' for a general speech about God's character.
quotes: Come ye, let us go up to the mountain of the LorD... (Isaiah 2:3)
So, Jesus says that God gives to us the perfect invitation: 'Come, ye blessed of my Father.'
The very word inherit calls to our minds a parent who has been thinking about us.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope and stick to it. Ask: what does Isaiah 2:3 say about the 'mountain of the Lord' that is not said elsewhere? Avoid jumping between unrelated verses to support a preconceived theme.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is virtually non-existent. There is no mention of the historical context of Isaiah or the eschatological framework of Matthew 25. The preacher relies on anecdotal comparisons (Greek mythology, personal stories) rather than the 'religious history and context of Israel.' The original meaning for the first readers is ignored in favor of a psychological interpretation of 'God's face.'
quotes: A great deal of this comes from the thinking of the ancient Greeks...
In the ancient account of Prometheus, the Greeks gave their idea of a reluctant God.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the Hebrew/Greek context. Explain why the 'mountain' or the 'house of the God of Jacob' mattered to a people in exile or under threat, rather than discussing Prometheus.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely psychological and general. While it touches on 'fear' and 'feeling abandoned,' it lacks the concrete social, political, or ecclesiastical specificity Dekker demands. It stays in the realm of 'general truths' about God's kindness, which Dekker explicitly forbids as 'not true truths.'
quotes: We think that good things are wrested from life and God only by sheer effort and careful scheming.
We are not ragamuffins or orphans sleeping under bridges or wherever we can steal a night's lodging.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond general moods of 'fear' to concrete contemporary situations. How does this specific text speak to the current zeitgeist or a specific congregational struggle?

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is almost no exposition, there is nothing to interweave. The sermon is a series of thematic applications of a general idea. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' because the text is merely a decorative frame for the preacher's own thoughts on God's friendliness.
quotes: This spirit is true, but it is not the whole truth. In his words 'Come, ye blessed of my Father,' Jesus is saying...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Let the application arise directly from the exegetical details. If the text mentions 'walking in paths,' apply the specific nature of those paths to modern life.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon acknowledges 'misery' (sinners, rebellion, fear) and 'redemption' (grace, Christ), but it treats misery more as a psychological state of feeling 'frightened of God' rather than a theological reality before God. Redemption is presented as God being 'kind' rather than a specific act of Christ.
quotes: Even as we bow, help us to remember that thou dost not hold us at a distance, though we are sinners.
We ought to despise the moods and days in which we have been frightened of God.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' part. It is not just a 'mood' to be despised, but a condition that requires the specific redemption offered in the text.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is surprisingly present. The preacher mentions the 'stern word' and the 'everlasting fire.' However, he quickly pivots to soften this with the 'perfect invitation,' potentially undermining the seriousness of the choice he just raised.
quotes: The chilling, final, terrible words are spoken: 'Depart from me,' he said, 'into everlasting fire...'
Jesus says that God gives to us the perfect invitation...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Allow the 'two ways' to remain as a serious call to responsibility rather than using the 'stern word' only as a foil to make the 'kind word' more appealing.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned frequently as the one who reveals God's kindness, but the sermon leans toward a general theism. Christ as the 'telos' (the goal) is obscured by a focus on the 'Father's smile.' The doctrine of the two natures is not utilized to ground the salvation outside of man.
quotes: Jesus does not support this idea... He saw everywhere signs of a tender, willing hand of love...
Jesus is saying that God is willing, anxious.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the specific 'telos.' Show how the 'perfect invitation' is only possible through the specific work of Christ, not just his role as a teacher of God's friendliness.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 15.5 minutes (1550 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' The rapid movement from Isaiah to Matthew to personal anecdotes prevents a deep drilling into the Word.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the substantive engagement with the text to reach at least 20 minutes. Replace anecdotes with deeper exegetical and dogmatic reflection.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily due to a lack of scriptural specificity and exegetical depth. It functions as a thematic address on the kindness of God rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. The use of Isaiah 2:3 is purely ornamental. While it correctly identifies the 'two ways' and the 'three parts' in the background, it prioritizes psychological comfort over theological confrontation with the Word.
strengths: Explicit mention of the 'two ways' and the reality of judgment, preventing a purely liberal sentimentality.
Clear focus on grace as the basis for the relationship with God.
Effective use of the 'three parts' (misery, redemption, gratitude) as a background structure.
weaknesses: Lack of specific pericope focus; the sermon is a 'speech about an idea' rather than a sermon.
Absence of original context/exegesis; the preacher ignores the historical and linguistic particularity of the text.
Insufficient length; at 15 minutes, it lacks the necessary breadth for homiletical depth.
Over-reliance on personal anecdotes and general psychological categories instead of concrete contemporary application.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s definition, this is not a sermon but a thematic speech. It fails the formal requirement of being an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage.' It is a bicycle mechanic who has failed to mount the wheel.
